ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES



Ironwood Midstream Energy Partners LLC (Ironwood) owns and operates a facility storage facility, the IMCP Gardendale Facility in La Salle County, Texas. The facility storage is designed to receives and stores butane and then inject it into crude oil line that will be delivered to end markets. 



Ironwood has a long-standing commitment to workers and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance, and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside agencies.



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The IMCP Gardendale Facility is located La Salle, Texas and operates a facility storage facility that storage the following product: 



1. Butane

2. Pentane



GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 



A. Process Safety Information



Ironwood keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These technical documents address the following:



1. Chemical properties and associated hazards

2. Necessary Block Flow Diagrams of the process

3. Maximum intended inventories

4. Upper and Lower limits of process fixed and rotating equipment

5. Equipment design basis and configuration information

6. Identification of all necessary Regulatory equipment design documents

7. Sufficient information to assure good engineering practices



The location of the technical documents referenced above is listed in the Process Safety Information portion of the PSM.



Chemical specific information, including hazard and emergency response/exposure consi

derations, is provided in safety data sheet (SDS). For specific process areas, the facility has documented safety- related limits for specific process parameters such as temperatures, level and composition in the operators' procedures manual. The facility maintains the process within these limits by using process controls and monitoring instruments, trained personnel and protective instrument systems such as automated shutdown systems.



The facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of the process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressures, temperature and electrical ratings. This information, in combination with procedures and equipment operating history, provides a basis for inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to safety features in the process are not compromised.



B. Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) 



Ironwood has a comprehensive program to identify and control hazards associated with the RMP covered process. This program systematically examines for potential hazards and puts controls in place to manage hazards. The team identifies, evaluates and makes recommendations to management of potential hazards identified. The team's findings are forward to Ironwood' Management for resolution. The approved mitigation options in response to the PHA team's findings are tracked until they are completed. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.



The facility periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.



C. Operating Procedures



Ironwood maintains written Operating Procedures of the covered process that address primary operations mandated by

OSHA, EPA, Good Engineering Practice and manufacturers. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. Procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current accurate by management. The procedures are maintained current and accurate revising them as necessary by employee's suggestion, compliance audit, PHAs, Good Engineering practice, Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) and implemented through Management of Change.



Covered Process Operating procedures are readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job task and maintain the covered process unit operating within its safe limits.



D. Training



Ironwood has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the covered process. New employees receive basic training in process operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. A performance review must be successfully completed during this training period. After the operator demonstrates adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they are allowed to work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years, or more frequently upon request. All training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify and demonstrate skills.



E. Safe Work Practices



Ironwood has standing safe work practices as mandated by OSHA, EPA, Industrial Standards and Good Engineering Practice in place to help provide employee, public and process safety.



F. Compliance Audits



At le

ast every 3 years a Compliance Audit addressing OSHA, EPA, RMP and Good Engineering Practices are conducted by employees and management of Ironwood. This audit team develops findings that are forwarded to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are completed. Final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.



G. Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The following is a description of existing features applicable to prevention of accidental release of regulated substances in this facility.



Universal Prevention Activities



Ironwood' accident release prevention and response policies are applied to all RMP-covered processes. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.



H. Specialized Safety Features



Site specific detection and control equipment (safety features) are deployed throughout the facility to:



1. Contain/control a release

2. Quickly detect a release, and

3. Reduce the consequences of an RMP-regulated substance release



The following type of safety features are used in the covered process: 



Release Detection



1. Level deviation alarm to contain liquids release

2. Reverse flow alarm to prevent reverse flow from the injection point

3. Beacon for alarm state and visual driver notification for improper normal or ESD shutdown

4. Hose inspection program to prevent rupture release hose failure

5. CSO designation for all safety device isolation valves to prevent trucking overfill



Release Mitigation



1. Fire extinguishers only

2. Trained emergency response personnel

3. Personal protective equipment



I. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



IMCP Gardendale Facility has had no RMP-regulated substance release during the past five years. 



J. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION



The facility maintains

a written emergency action plan, which is in place to help protect employees and public safety as well as the environment. The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release including: proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.



Employees receive training in the procedures to be followed by employees who remain to operate critical facility operations before they evacuate. Ironwood has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (Fire Department, Police, Sheriff's Office, or similar). This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition, Ironwood conducts periodic emergency drills and annual refresher training for facility personnel.



K. Planned changes to improve safety



Ironwood's management is committed to the following:



1. Preventing accidents;

2. Training our employees in correct response procedures in the event of an accident;

3. Participating in community emergency preparedness;

4. Addressing any citizen concerns by fully explaining potential hazards associated with Ironwood operations and all steps being taken to prevent and mitigate accidents.



With these objectives in mind, this Risk Management Plan has been developed to provide information about our management of the risks associated with the natural gas treatment and liquids recovery process. Most importantly, we stress our commitment to ensuring a safe operation for our employees, our visitors, and our community.
